name: Adam
description: God formed Adam from the dust and created Eve from his rib. They lived in perfect fellowship with God in the Garden of Eden.
bio: God formed Adam from the dust and created Eve from his rib. They lived in perfect fellowship with God in the Garden of Eden.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Eve
description: Eve was the first woman, formed from Adam's rib to be his companion. She was deceived by the serpent in the Garden of Eden and, along with Adam, introduced sin into the world.
bio: Eve was created by God from Adam's rib to be his companion. Together they were tempted by the serpent and disobeyed God.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Cain
description: Cain was the firstborn son of Adam and Eve, a farmer by trade. After God rejected his offering, he murdered his brother Abel out of jealousy and was cursed to be a restless wanderer.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Able
description: Abel was the second son of Adam and Eve, a keeper of flocks. His faithful offering pleased God, but he was murdered by his brother Cain, becoming the first martyr in Scripture.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Seth
description: Seth was the third named son of Adam and Eve, born after Abel's death. Through his line the godly lineage continued, eventually leading to Noah and ultimately to Christ.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Noah
description: Noah was a righteous man who walked with God. He built the ark and preserved humanity and animal kinds through the Flood.
bio: Noah was a righteous man who walked with God. He built the ark and preserved humanity and animal kinds through the Flood.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Abraham
description: Abraham (originally Abram) is the father of the Hebrew nation. God called him to leave Ur and promised to make him a great nation and bless all families of the earth through him.
bio: Abraham (originally Abram) is the father of the Hebrew nation. God called him to leave Ur and promised to make him a great nation and bless all families of the earth through him.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Isaac
description: Isaac was the promised son born to Abraham and Sarah in their old age. He became the father of Jacob (Israel) and continued God’s covenant line.
bio: The promised son of Abraham and Sarah, born when they were elderly. Nearly sacrificed by Abraham as a test of faith. Married Rebekah and fathered Jacob and Esau.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Jacob (Israel)
description: Jacob (later renamed Israel) was the younger twin son of Isaac. He fathered the twelve tribes of Israel and received the covenant blessing from God.
bio: Jacob (later renamed Israel) was the younger twin son of Isaac. He fathered the twelve tribes of Israel and received the covenant blessing from God.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Levi
description: Levi was the third son of Jacob and Leah, and the ancestor of Israel's priestly tribe. The Levites were set apart by God to serve in the tabernacle and later the temple.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Judah
description: Judah was the fourth son of Jacob and Leah, whose tribe became the ruling tribe of Israel. The Messianic line passed through Judah, fulfilling Jacob's prophecy that the scepter would not depart from his descendants.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Joseph
description: Joseph was Jacob's favored son, sold into slavery by his jealous brothers. Through God's providence he rose to become second-in-command of Egypt and saved his family from famine.
bio: Sold into slavery by his brothers, Joseph rose to become second-in-command in Egypt. He saved Egypt and his family from famine through God-given wisdom.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Aaron
description: Aaron was Moses' older brother and Israel's first high priest. He served as Moses' spokesman before Pharaoh and was consecrated to lead Israel's priesthood, though he also led the people in making the golden calf.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Moses
description: Born during Pharaoh’s infanticide, Moses was raised in Pharaoh’s court, fled to Midian, and later led Israel out of Egypt. He received the Law at Sinai.
bio: Born in Egypt during Hebrew slavery, Moses was rescued by Pharaoh's daughter. Called by God at the burning bush, he led Israel out of Egypt and received the Law at Sinai.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Joshua
description: (originally named Hoshea) was Moses’ longtime assistant and the faithful military leader who succeeded him as the commander of Israel. He courageously led the Israelites across the Jordan River into the Promised Land, directed the conquest of Canaan.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Boaz
description: Boaz was a wealthy and godly landowner in Bethlehem who served as the kinsman-redeemer for Ruth. He married Ruth, and their son Obed became the grandfather of King David.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Ruth
description: Ruth was a Moabite woman who faithfully followed her mother-in-law Naomi back to Bethlehem after her husband's death. Her loyalty and devotion led to her marriage to Boaz, placing her in the lineage of King David and ultimately Christ.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Samuel
description: Samuel was the last judge, a prophet, and priest. He anointed Israel’s first two kings (Saul and David) and called the nation back to faithfulness to God.
bio: Samuel was the last judge, a prophet, and priest. He anointed Israel's first two kings (Saul and David) and called the nation back to faithfulness to God.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Jesse
description: Jesse was the grandson of Boaz and Ruth and the father of King David. He lived in Bethlehem, where the prophet Samuel came to anoint one of his sons as the future king of Israel.
bio: A Bethlehemite of the tribe of Judah. Father of eight sons including David. Grandson of Ruth and Boaz.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: David
description: David was a shepherd boy anointed by Samuel who became Israel's greatest king, uniting the nation and establishing Jerusalem as its capital. He was called a man after God's own heart and received the covenant promise that his throne would endure forever.
bio: A shepherd from Bethlehem, David was anointed king by Samuel. He united Israel, conquered Jerusalem, and established a dynasty through which the Messiah would come.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Solomon
description: Solomon was the son of David and Bathsheba who succeeded his father as king of Israel. Renowned for his God-given wisdom, he built the first temple in Jerusalem but later turned to idolatry through his many foreign wives.
bio: Third king of Israel, known for wisdom granted by God. Built the First Temple in Jerusalem. Author of Proverbs, Ecclesiastes, and Song of Solomon. His reign marked Israel's golden age.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Jeroboam I
description: First king of the northern kingdom of Israel
bio: Led the rebellion against Rehoboam and became the first king of the breakaway northern kingdom. Set up golden calves at Dan and Bethel, establishing idolatrous worship.

name: Rehoboam
description: First king of the southern kingdom of Judah
bio: Son of Solomon whose harsh response to the northern tribes' petition caused the kingdom to split. Ruled Judah and Benjamin from Jerusalem.

name: Asa
description: Reformer king of Judah
bio: Third king of Judah who instituted religious reforms, removed idols, and fortified cities. Relied on God early but later turned to foreign alliances.

name: Ahab
description: Wicked king of Israel, husband of Jezebel
bio: Married the Phoenician princess Jezebel and promoted Baal worship throughout Israel. Confronted by Elijah at Mount Carmel. Killed in battle at Ramoth-gilead.

name: Jehoshaphat
description: Godly king who strengthened Judah
bio: Strengthened Judah's defenses and sent Levites to teach the Law throughout the land. Allied with Ahab against Aram but was rebuked by the prophet Jehu.

name: Elijah
description: Elijah was a powerful prophet who confronted the worship of Baal in the northern kingdom of Israel, most famously on Mount Carmel. He was taken up to heaven in a chariot of fire without experiencing death.
bio: Dramatic prophet who challenged Ahab and Jezebel's Baal worship. Called down fire from heaven on Mount Carmel. Taken to heaven in a chariot of fire.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Elisha
description: Elisha was the prophet who succeeded Elijah after receiving a double portion of his spirit. He performed many miracles throughout his ministry, including healing Naaman's leprosy and raising a widow's son from the dead.
bio: Received a double portion of Elijah's spirit. Performed numerous miracles including healing Naaman's leprosy and raising the Shunammite's son.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Obadiah
description: Obadiah authored the shortest book in the Old Testament, a single chapter of prophecy against Edom. He condemned the Edomites for their pride and for gloating over Judah's destruction at the hands of Babylon.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Jehu
description: King of Israel who destroyed Baal worship
bio: Anointed by Elisha's servant to destroy the house of Ahab. Killed Joram, Jezebel, and all Baal worshippers, but continued Jeroboam's calf worship.

name: Joel
description: Joel was a prophet who used a devastating locust plague as a backdrop to call Judah to repentance. He prophesied about the coming Day of the Lord and the future outpouring of God's Spirit on all people.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Jeroboam II
description: Powerful king who restored Israel's borders
bio: Longest and most prosperous reign of any northern king. Restored Israel's borders from Lebo-hamath to the Sea of the Arabah. Despite material prosperity, spiritual decline continued.

name: Jonah
description: Jonah was a prophet sent by God to preach repentance to the Assyrian city of Nineveh. After fleeing from God's call and being swallowed by a great fish, he obeyed and Nineveh repented.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Amos
description: Amos was a shepherd and fig farmer from Tekoa whom God called to prophesy against the northern kingdom of Israel. His message focused on social justice, condemning the oppression of the poor and Israel's empty religious rituals.
bio: A shepherd from Tekoa in Judah sent to prophesy against the northern kingdom. Denounced social injustice, religious hypocrisy, and predicted exile.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Hosea
description: Hosea was a prophet to the northern kingdom whose marriage to the unfaithful Gomer served as a living parable. His life illustrated God's steadfast love for Israel despite her spiritual adultery and idolatry.
bio: God commanded Hosea to marry an unfaithful wife as a living parable of Israel's spiritual adultery. Prophesied during Israel's final decades before Assyrian exile.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Zechariah
description: Zechariah was a post-exilic prophet and priest who, alongside Haggai, encouraged the rebuilding of the temple. His book contains vivid apocalyptic visions and striking Messianic prophecies about Christ's entry into Jerusalem and His eventual reign.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Isaiah
description: Isaiah was a major prophet who ministered in Judah during the reigns of four kings, calling the nation to repentance and trust in God. His prophecies contain some of the most detailed Messianic predictions in Scripture, including the suffering servant passages.
bio: Called in a vision of God's throne. Prophesied during the reigns of Uzziah through Hezekiah. Wrote extensively about the coming Messiah and Israel's restoration.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Micah
description: Micah was a prophet from the small town of Moresheth who prophesied against both Samaria and Jerusalem. He famously foretold that the Messiah would be born in Bethlehem and called Israel to act justly, love mercy, and walk humbly with God.
bio: Contemporary of Isaiah from the countryside town of Moresheth. Pronounced judgment on both Israel and Judah. Predicted the Messiah would be born in Bethlehem.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Hoshea
description: Last king of the northern kingdom
bio: Last king of Israel. Conspired against Pekah and became an Assyrian vassal. His secret alliance with Egypt provoked the Assyrian siege and fall of Samaria in 721 BC.

name: Hezekiah
description: Reformer king who trusted God against Assyria
bio: One of Judah's greatest kings. Restored Temple worship, celebrated Passover, and trusted God when Sennacherib besieged Jerusalem. God miraculously delivered the city.

name: Manasseh
description: Supporting biblical figure linked through family or narrative relationships.

name: Nehum
description: Nahum was a prophet whose message focused on the coming destruction of Nineveh, the Assyrian capital. His prophecy declared God's judgment against Assyria's cruelty and violence, comforting Judah with the promise of their oppressor's downfall.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Jeremiah
description: Jeremiah was called as a prophet while still young and ministered to Judah for over 40 years leading up to and during the Babylonian exile. Known as the weeping prophet, he faithfully proclaimed God's judgment despite intense personal suffering and rejection.
bio: Called as a young man to prophesy Judah's destruction. Witnessed the fall of Jerusalem and the exile. Promised a new covenant written on hearts.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Zephaniah
description: Zephaniah was a prophet of royal descent who ministered during King Josiah's reign in Judah. He proclaimed the coming Day of the Lord as a time of judgment on Judah's idolatry, but also promised a future restoration for a faithful remnant.
bio: Royal descendant who prophesied during Josiah's reign. Proclaimed the coming Day of the Lord as universal judgment, but also promised restoration for a faithful remnant.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Josiah
description: Last great reformer king of Judah
bio: Became king at age 8. Found the Book of the Law during Temple repairs and led the most thorough reform in Judah's history. Killed at Megiddo fighting Pharaoh Necho.

name: Daniel
description: Daniel was a young Jewish nobleman taken captive to Babylon who rose to serve as a high official under multiple empires. He remained faithful to God throughout his life, receiving apocalyptic visions and surviving the lions' den.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Ezekiel
description: Ezekiel was a priest and prophet who ministered to the Jewish exiles in Babylon during the captivity. His dramatic visions and symbolic acts conveyed God's judgment on Jerusalem and His promise to restore Israel, including the famous vision of the valley of dry bones.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Habakkuk
description: Habakkuk was a prophet who boldly questioned God about why He allowed injustice in Judah and why He would use the wicked Babylonians as instruments of judgment. God's response taught him that the righteous shall live by faith, a truth later central to the New Testament.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Zedekiah
description: Last king of Judah
bio: Installed as puppet king by Nebuchadnezzar. Rebelled against Babylon despite Jeremiah's warnings. Jerusalem fell, he was blinded and taken to Babylon.

name: Haggai
description: Haggai was a post-exilic prophet who urged the returned Jewish community to complete the rebuilding of the temple in Jerusalem. His short but powerful messages motivated the people to prioritize God's house over their own comfort.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Esther
description: Esther was a Jewish woman who became queen of Persia during the reign of King Xerxes (Ahasuerus). She courageously risked her life to save the Jewish people from a plot of annihilation devised by the official Haman.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.

name: Malachi
description: Malachi was the last Old Testament prophet, ministering to the post-exilic community in Jerusalem. He confronted the people's spiritual apathy, corrupt worship, and broken covenants, while pointing ahead to the coming messenger who would prepare the way for the Lord.
source: Hindson, Ed, and Gary Yates, editors. The Essence of the Old Testament: A Survey. B&H Academic, 2012. Walton, John H. Chronological and Background Charts of the Old Testament. Revised and Expanded ed., Zondervan Academic, 1994. The Holy Bible, New International Version. Zondervan, 2011.
